p: The historical usage of microbial secondary metabolites dates back to ancient civilizations in different food recipes and beverages for curing various ailments [ 37]. Using in-vitro, in-vivo and in-silico approaches, the present study evaluated the antidiabetic and antioxidant, properties of a microbial extract. In the present study, type 2 diabetes was induced in test rats by feeding them corticosteroids and a high sucrose diet, which has been reported to promote gluconeogenesis without adversely impacting carbohydrate metabolism [ 38]. Corticosteroids harm insulin signaling and functioning, resulting in insulin resistance [ 39]. Based on this effect, glucose homeostasis indices, including insulin resistance, reduced insulin sensitivity, and Î²-cell dysfunction, were assessed in test rats that were induced to be diabetic [ 40]. Insulin-resistant rats are unable to utilize glucose [ 41] correctly.
